description: Daria Tomenko authenticates Halden's Spiral Manifesto. She chooses to share it with key grassroots organizers, rejecting the release of the BCI forgiveness protocol and opting to inspire a cultural shift instead of forced amnesty.

An artist collective, backed by local assembly leaders, publicly presents the Spiral Manifesto. The text advocates moving from punitive surveillance to personal growth, mutual aid, and cyclical leadership. Debate erupts across Stenograd.
Neighborhood assemblies and forums replace punitive proceedings with open debates, piloting flexible leadership rotations and focusing on reconciliation instead of past BCI scores.
Street courts are suspended across the city. Communities hold testimonial gatherings, guided by the Spiral Manifesto’s call for mutual recognition and personal renewal.

A citywide celebration officially marks the foundation of the 'spiral system,' committing Stenograd to a recovery process centered on mutual support, education, and shared civic responsibility. BCI-driven divisions are gradually phased out.
